Exaggerate: The claim may be seen as exaggerating the presence of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) at every polling station on Nov. 3, 2020.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to prove that ICE will be present at every polling station on the specified date.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that ICE will be actively involved in the electoral process, which is not supported by factual information.
Exist alternative explanation: The alternative explanation is provided by ICE itself, stating that they do not patrol or conduct enforcement operations at polling locations.
Falters at times: The claim falters in terms of accuracy and reliability, as it is flagged as false by Facebook and contradicted by the official statement from ICE.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that ICE will not be present at polling stations on Nov. 3, 2020, as confirmed by the federal agency.
Understate: There is no evidence to suggest that the claim understates any aspect.
